data.title: The theory for EURO 2024 still exists, but the Falcons will have to outdo themselves
data.meta_description: All victories until the end of the qualifiers lead Montenegro to Germany, and four consecutive triumphs in competitive matches have been tied by the Falcons only once in history - in the qualifiers...
data.text:
When you lose two crucial points against a team that has recorded 50 defeats and only four wins in the last 34 competitive matches, then the talk of qualifying for the European Championship seems a bit frivolous.

Especially when the impression is reinforced by the unconvincing and almost idealess game against Lithuania (2:2) at the "Darius i Girenas" stadium in Kaunas.

Nevertheless, the theory says that the football team of Montenegro still has a chance to qualify for EURO 2024 in Germany, and as long as there is a chance, the "falcons" should not give up.

However, Miodrag Radulović's boys will have to surpass themselves and erase some bad things from the past until the end of the qualification.

To begin with, they will have to overcome Bulgaria under Gorica for the first time in history (after three draws), and then Serbia in the middle of Belgrade, to whom they gave only a goal in the previous three matches, to be better than Hungary in Budapest, to "take revenge". Lithuania...

In translation, all the victories until the end of the qualifiers lead Montenegro to Germany, and the "falcons" have tied their four victories in a row in competitive matches only once in history - in the qualifiers for the 2014 World Cup, when they defeated San Marino, Ukraine and Moldova twice.

Lithuania and Bulgaria could make Montenegro's job easier, with possible victories over Serbia, but the question is how realistic that is.

All the mentioned matches will be decisive, and over the past fifteen years we have also learned that Montenegrin footballers mostly lost such matches.

Chernih, Gazarjan, Zabicer, Georgiev

Fedor Chernyh "stole" two points from Montenegro yesterday in Kaunas with a great goal in the 94th minute, and it was the fourth time that the "falcons" lost points in stoppage time.

In the qualifiers for the 2010 World Cup, Blagoj Georgijev shocked Podgorica with a free kick in the 92nd and gave Bulgaria a point (2:2), while Montenegro lost a 2016:2 lead against Austria "under Gorica" ​​in the EURO 1 - Marcel Zabicer scored the goal for the turnaround in the visitors' victory in the 92nd minute.

In the qualifiers for the 2018 World Cup, Montenegro lost an even bigger advantage in Yerevan (2:0) - Gevor Gazarjan scored a goal in the 93rd to direct a great turnaround for Armenia (3:2).
